title: A FOUR-PART STORY
author: ALAN BARNES
filename: 127 - Castle of Fear (The Stockbridge Trilogy 1) - Alan Barnes_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: EXT. GREEN DRAGON INN (1899)
(FX: A TRADITIONAL MUMMERS’ PLAY IN PROGRESS OUTSIDE A VILLAGE
PUB. NOISY CROWD WATCHING)
(TO CROWD) Here come I, old Father Christmas, Welcome you, or welcome not;
I am not come here for to laugh or to jeer,
But for a pocketful of money, and a skinful of beer!
FX: BEERY GUFFAWS FROM CROWD. CROSS TO:
(IN CROWD, SLIGHTLY DISAPPROVING) Doctor? This ‘skinful’ is part of the ‘mimery’ too?
(BESIDE HER) Mummery, Nyssa. Well, it is Christmas.
‘Boxing Day’, you said. It sounds utterly barbaric.
Ah. No boxing. Not on Boxing Day.
Obviously.
Just — enjoy the play, Nyssa. As best you can.
FX: CROWD BOOS AS THE TURKISH KNIGHT BARGES THROUGH
(PLAYING THE BAD GUY TO CROWD) Here come I, the Turkish Knight; Come from the Turkish land to fight!
Doctor — if this is England, why is there a Turkish Knight?
Well, the mummers’ play is an oral tradition, passed down since the Middle Ages. With local variations, of course.
You don’t know.
I’ve absolutely no idea. Look — here’s Saint George!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
FX: CHEERS FROM CROWD
Here come I, Saint George, from England did I spring; I’ll fight the Dragon bold, my wonders to begin!
FX: ENTER DRAGON. CROWD ROARS
Who’s he that seeks the Dragon’s blood, And calls so angry, and so loud?
FX: CROSS TO:
That’s a dragon?
The costumes could do with a little work, I grant you.
FX: CROSS TO:
. That English dog, will he before me stand? I’1l1 cut him down with my vicious hand!
I’1ll clip his wings, he shall not fly; I’1l cut him down, or else I die! (ROARS AS HE ATTACKS DRAGON)
FX: GEORGE/DRAGON PLAYFIGHT CONTINUES UNDER AS WE CROSS TO:
Doctor, when you suggested spending Christmas in Stockbridge,
and I said, ‘Please, not the twenty-first century’
Awkward, you said. (EMBARRASSED) With, you know —
NYSSA3: Andrew. That’s his name. I didn’t mean it.
(‘YOU DIDN’T?’) Oh.
Well, I did and I didn’t. But 1899 is too primitive for me.
(DISAPPOINTED) Right. Yes. Very well.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 3
We can see the play to the end, though. Unless you saw it last Christmas.
I’ve not been in Stockbridge earlier than this. But never mind, we can catch it in — 2008? 2009?
We can?

I told you, the words have been passed down, father to son, for hundreds of years. These people’s descendants will be playing the same parts on Boxing Day morning — well, for a few more centuries yet. Perhaps Andrew will be among them.
(SARCASTIC) I doubt that.
FX: INTERRUPTED BY EXAGGERATED DYING HOWL FROM DRAGON
At last, at last, the monster is slay’d;
But look at the mess his claws have made! (EXAGGERATED FAINT)
FX: FALLS TO FLOOR — ‘ARMOUR’ CLATTERS
Is there a doctor to be found All ready, near at hand;
To cure a deep and deadly wound, And make the champion stand?
FX: CROSS TO:
(CALLING OUT) Over here!
Nyssa!
FX: NO-ONE TAKES ANY NOTICE; THE PLAY CONTINUES
Sorry, I couldn’t resist. This is getting sillier by the minute: Father Christmas, St George, a dragon and now a doctor.
The doctor is a common figure in mummery. An agent of death and rebirth, some say of seasonal renewal.
FX: CROSS TO:
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 4
(INTO DISTANCE) Ah yes! The Doctor! See, he arrives; In his strange blue cart, smaller on the out than it is inside!
FX: CROSS TO:
Carry him through! Carry him through!
Doctor, that’s a big blue box!
Yes, well, I’m sure it’s just a coincidence.
(OFF) Out, Doctor, out; From your cart, larger within that it is without!
Out! Out! Out, Doctor, out!
You’re sure you’ve never been in Stockbridge earlier than this?
Really, I haven’t.
FX: CROSS TO CHEERS AS ‘DOCTOR’ EMERGES FROM BOX
MUMMER PLAYING ‘DOCTOR’:
Oh! Yes, there is a Doctor near at hand,
Ready to make the champion stand.
Not another paltry mime;
But an Earl of Space, and a Lord of Time!
FX: CROSS TO:
What did he say?
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
SCENE 2: EXT. WOODLAND TRACK (1199)
FX: 2 x HORSES RIDING TO HALT
Sire? We take the left-hand path? Or the right?
I — I’m not sure, good Yavuz. It’s this fog.
‘Tis a strange mist that makes one’s homeland unfamiliar. Cold and cloying, like chickpea broth.
A real bean-souper, yes. Damned unseasonable, too. (FX: GATHERING REINS) Right. I mean — left!
You are sure, sire?
(DECISIVELY) Left. Stockbridge Castle must be but a half-mile further. I think —
(HISSING) Quiet!
Yavuz?
A woman approaches.
They do?
Listen!
(FX: MAUD IS WALKING TOWARDS THEM ALONG THE TRACK, SINGING ‘BIRD ON A BRIAR’ SOFTLY TO HERSELF: MELODY AT www. luminarium.org/medlit/medlyric/brere. php)
Bryd one brere, brid, brid one brere, Kynd is come of love, love to crave Blythful biryd, on me thu rewe
Or greyth, lef, greith thu me my grave —
(ALOUD) You there! Halt!
Mercy, mercy!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 6
(TO HUBERT) What is this sign she makes with her hands?
(TO MAUD) Cross yourself all you like, crone, it won’t trouble my heathen knight here. Is this the road to the castle?
I beg you, devils: I am a good woman of Stockbridge, gathering herbs. I makes tonics, and potions! Please, let me pass!
Stockbridge?
(TO YAVUZ) What did I tell you, Yavuz? Stockbridge Castle: half a mile yonder on the left!
Forgive me, sirs, but ‘tis two miles yonder and on the right- hand path!
LAUGHS
(TO SELF) Damn!
(TO MAUD) What is your name, ‘good woman’?
I am Maud the Withered, a true and honest maiden of Mummerset!
Come closer, Maud the Withered. Tell me — do you not know this man, my master?
By his father’s eyes, perhaps?
Ah, but I hadn’t started shaving when I first departed England, seven years since.
I don’t understand.
This is your master, too! Hubert, Earl of Mummerset — returned at last from Palestine!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 7
Hubert, Earl of Mummerset?
Yes.
Come to claim his father’s title?
Yes.
Come to claim his castle, and his lands?
Yes!
CACKLES LONG AND LOUD
Wh-what?
What’s so funny, woman?
(STILL LAUGHING) You don’t know?
Don’t know what?
Why, my Lord — in your absence, devils took your father, and his castle!
(SNEERING) Devils!
Devils and goblins, imps and demons! It is not your castle! Not any more!
Now, look — it very well is, by right of birth!
Go back, Hubert of Mummerset! Retreat from this unholy land! This is the Earldom of Lucifer now!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
SCENE 3: EXT. GREEN DRAGON INN
FX: THE MUMMERS’ PLAY CONTINUES OFF
MUMMER PLAYING ‘DOCTOR’: (OFF) .. The phthisic, the palsy, and the gout; Whatever disorder, I’1l soon pull him out!
Doctor, this can’t be right. He’s you! He’s even dressed like you!
It’s a white coat, that’s all.
Yes, and the celery?
FX: CROSS TO:
MUMMER PLAYING ‘DOCTOR’: Here, George, take a little of my flip-flop; Pour it down thy tip-top: Rise up, and fight again!
LOUD COMEDY ‘GLUG... GLUG... GLUG’; BEAT; LOUD COMEDY BELCH
ROWDY APPLAUSE, CHEERS
Here am I, Saint George, that worthy champion bold! I fought the fiery dragon, and brought him to the slaughter!
FX: CROSS
Fascinating, I agree, but this ‘doctor’ isn’t me!
Are you sure about that?
Nyssa, I’m known throughout history for many things. Bringing the dead back to life is not one of them!
(FX: CROSS BACK. CROWD MAKES OMINOUS ROAR — ‘WHOAAAAA...’ — AS TURKISH KNIGHT SNEAKS UP BEHIND ST GEORGE)
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 9
Where is the Turk that will before me stand? I’11 cut him down with my courageous hand!
Here, sir! Yaaa! (ROARS, CHARGES)
(FX: CROSS BACK AS TURKISH KNIGHT AND GEORGE BEGIN PLAY FIGHT. CROWD GASPING AND LAUGHING THROUGHOUT, CLUNKING SOUNDS OF WOODEN SWORDS STRIKING WOODEN SHIELDS)
Over there — that’s the Green Dragon Inn. Perhaps — perhaps the play commemorates a specific event, in the past? The same event remembered in the name of the pub?
Nyssa, there must be hundreds of Green Dragon Inns in the country.
(LOST IN THOUGHT) .. An event involving you, a green dragon...
(SCEPTICAL) .. and a Turkish Knight?
FX: CROSS BACK TO THE PLAY AS THE KNIGHTS’ SCUFFLE ENDS
Pardon me, Saint George, pardon of thee I crave; Pardon me this night, and I will be thy slave.
I’1ll never pardon a Turkish Knight; So rise thee up again, if you might! (EFFORT — ‘KILLS’ KNIGHT)
‘DEATH CRY’
FX: CROWD CHEERS. CROSS BACK
Well, when you put it like that...
Exactly. It’s hardly likely that the whole of mumming tradition derives from one specific incident involving me!
(OFF) Ladies and gentlemen, our sport is now ended, So prepare for our box, which is highly commended; Come, throw in your money, and think it no wrong!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
FX: OFF, CHINKS OF COINAGE IN BOX
(PROMPTING) Doctox...?
(PATTING POCKETS) Oh! Yes. I’m sure I’ve a farthing or two somewhere...
FX: CROSS BACK
And should you wish to see our Play again,
We’ll show it once more, down the lane;
The Green Dragon Inn has seen all our celebration, But follow us, all — the Turk’s Head is waiting!
FX: CHEERS. CROSS BACK
Did he say...?
. The Turk’s Head, yes.
NYSSA & DOCTOR: (TOGETHER) .. A Turkish Knight!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page I]
SCENE 4: EXT. CASTLE GATE
FX: 2 x HORSES CLOP TO HALT ON STONE BRIDGE. WHINNY
(UNIMPRESSED) What, this is it?
Stockbridge [Castle] — what d’you mean, ‘This is it?’
The battlements are only as high as ten men on end — but you spoke of it as the largest fortress in the Western Countries!
Counties. And yes, you stand before the largest fortress in the whole of Mummersetshire!
Then the devils inside must truly be terrible, to drive your servants from the safety of its walls.
What? You took that crone at her word?
She had no reason to lie.
She’s but a credulous Saxon. It’s a well-known fact, the native Angles have smaller brains than those of Normandy stock.
Then, my Lord, with your Norman brain, tell me: how shall we enter within, with no gatekeeper to raise the portcullis?
Oh, that’s easy.
Aaaah, there is a secret entrance?
No, Yavuz. You climb the battlements.
I what?
They are only as high as ten men on end.
B-but.
Better get to it. Before night falls.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 5: EXT. TURK’S HEAD
FX: CROWD HUBBUB
(WALKING UP) Here we are. (READING SIGN) ‘The Turk’s Head’.
One moment, Nyssa. (CALLING OFF) Excuse me! Father, uh, Christmas?
Later, sir! Our play is about to begin — (DOUBLE-TAKE) Ah, but you’ve come dressed for the occasion. ‘Doctor’!
I beg your pardon?
With your coat, and your reviving vegetable?
Told you.
(IGNORING HER) I was wondering if I could talk to you about the origin of the play text?
(FROM OFF; ‘NORMAL’ VOICE) Jack! Jack!!!
One moment, sir.
(RUSHING UP) Jack, it’s old man Grubb. He can hardly stand.
There’s no surprise. He’s been knocking them back since the Redfern. It’s fortunate that I’ve a fellow here to stand in his stead!
I’m sorry, I don’t follow.
Tell the others. (CALLING OUT) Positions, men!
Doctor, they want you to take his place!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 13
(FX: TURNING ASIDE) Aye, and well volunteered it was!
But —
(TO CROWD) Here come I, old Father Christmas,
Welcome you, or welcome not;
[I am not come here for to laugh or to jeer,
But for a pocketful of money, and a skinful of beer!]
FX: OVER THIS:
Sorry, Nyssa, this isn’t what I intended.
No rush, Doctor. I’m enjoying myself immensely!
SCENE 6: EXT. CASTLE GATE/BATTLEMENTS
(FX: CHINK OF METAL STIRRUP AGAINST STONE — YAVUZ IS CLIMBING THE CASTLE BATTLEMENTS )
EFFORT
(BELOW, CALLING UP) Come on, Yavuz! You told me you climbed the cliffs at Masada!
(TO SELF, THROUGH GRITTED TEETH) Yes, sire. But the heights at Masada are not coated in this — putrescent moss — (MAKES FINAL EFFORT)
FX: CROSS TO BELOW
Pardon?
(FROM ABOVE, KNACKERED) Ha! See? I have made it! Ha ha!
(CALLING UP) Very good, well done. Now just hop down the other Side, and raise the portcullis.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 14
(FROM ABOVE) Again, it is the height of ten men on end!
(CALLING UP) Jump, then!
(FROM ABOVE) It is dark too! I shall take the steps!
Oh, yes. The steps. (CALLING UP) Jolly good!
FX: CROSS TO:
(FX: CLATTERING DOWN STEPS) Hop, he says. Jump, he says. He of the ‘Normandy [stock’ —] (SLIPS, CRIES OUT, TUMBLES)
FX: CLATTER. CROSS BACK
(CALLING OUT) Yavuz-? Yavuz-? Oh, don’t say you’ve broken your neck!
(FX: AT GROUND LEVEL, JUST A FEW FEET AWAY, THE OTHER SIDE OF THE PORTCULLIS) (STIRS, DAZED)
Ah! I see you now. Have you, er, have you broken your neck?
(WITH BRUISED PRIDE) These steps are covered in moss! (BEAT) I shall raise the portcullis.
Good, good.
But — where is the mechanism?
Oh! Um —
The lever, or some like device?
(SPECULATIVE — HE DOESN’T KNOW THERE’S A GATEHOUSE) Try — the gatehouse? Around the side?
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 15
Side of what?
Well, the gate?
FX: YAVUZ MOVING OFF
BEAT
Hurry it up. I swear this fog is getting worse, I can barely see the path we rode in on.
(OFF) .. here! I have found it! (FX: IRON RATTLE) It is barred, though.
FX: WHUMP OF DISCHARGED ELECTRICAL ENERGY, OFF
OFF, SCREAMS
Yavuz? You haven’t slipped again, have you? (FX: SHAKING PORTCULLIS) Yavuz?
OFF) Demon, get back! (FX: ANOTHER DISCHARGE) (SCREAMS AGAIN
D-demon?!?
(OFF) Run, sire! Run! Before this devil takes you too!
FX: ANOTHER DISCHARGE... AND SILENCE
BEAT
Yavuz? Yavuz? (COLLECTING HIS WITS) Run. Yes. Yes! Run!!!
FX: FLEES OVER COBBLES
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 7: EXT. TURK’S HEAD
FX: PLAY IN PROGRESS. EXAGGERATED DYING HOWL FROM DRAGON
At last, at last, the monster is slay’d; But look at the mess his claws have made! (EXAGGERATED FAINT)
Is there a doctor to be found All ready, near at hand;
To cure a deep and deadly wound, And make the champion stand?
(CALLING OUT) Over here!
(PAINED) Nyssa. I really don’t think-
Don’t be a killjoy.
(INTO DISTANCE) Ah yes! The Doctor! See, he arrives.
(STRUGGLING FREE OF CROWD) No, I shan’t be needing my ‘strange blue cart’ today. Thank you. Now, uh — what seems to be the [problem-? ]
BEGINS TO BOO DOCTOR
Oh. Did I do something wrong?
(SOTTO) You’ve not introduced yourself properly, sir!
Say what’s on the card, Doctor! “Oh! Yes, there is a Doctor near at hand —”
Of course. (FLAT) ”.. a Doctor near at hand/Ready to make the champion stand. I am not another paltry mime;
But an Earl of Space, and...” (BEAT) Oh, the rest you know. Now,
Saint George, what seems to be the problem?
The problem is — you’ve ruined our play, sir!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
LAUGHS
Sorry. Sorry!
Just read it off the card! (PROMPT) ‘Here, George-?’
(READING) Here, George, take a little of the flip-flop; Pour it down your tip-top:
Rise up, and fight again!
LOUD COMEDY ‘GLUG... GLUG... GLUG’; BEAT; LOUD COMEDY BELCH
ROWDY APPLAUSE, CHEERS
Here am I, Saint George, that worthy champion bold! I fought the fiery dragon, and brought him to the slaughter.
(BOOMING) No! He shall not defeat us!
(SOTTO) Eh? What’s he playing at?
(SOTTO) Oh, Doctor, you’ve messed it up!
Doctor? This is the Doctor?
“.. an Earl of Space, and a [Lord of Time!]”
Time Lord. Yes.
I say, are you alright?
Time... Lord!
“IT fought the fiery dragon, and brought him to the slaughter”
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 18
Stand aside, strange knight. This is not your business.
(WADING IN) Alright, alright. Maybe a quart of ale will put out
our Dragon’s fire?
YOKEL 1: I’d say he’s had more’n a quart already!
LAUGHS. OVER THIS:
(TO DRAGON ACTOR) Come on now, Edward. Lie down and let’s get on with it.
You too, drone! My business is with the Time... Lord!
Lie down, sir.
FX: CHINK OF CLAWS ON HELMET
HOWLS IN PAIN
SHOCK
(FAINT) Oh, but look what a mess his claws have made.
(TO DRAGON) Edward! Whatever’s possessed you, man?
Whatever indeed?
Now, Time Lord. (LUNGING) Now for you!
Doctor, look out!
FX: THE ROAR OF THE DRAGON AS HE FLINGS HIMSELF AT THE DOCTOR
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 19
SCENE 8: EXT. STOCKBRIDGE VILLAGE
(FX: FADE UP. CROWD HUBBUB. WE EXPERIENCE THIS FROM THE
HUBERT IS A LITTLE WAY OFF. THINK ‘BLESSED ARE THE CHEESEMAKERS’. )
YOKEL 1: What’s this Norman puppy?
YOKEL 2: Only the Earl o’ Mummerset, they says.
YOKEL 1: Who says?
YOKEL 2: Maud.
YOKEL 1: What, Maud the Strumpet?
YOKEL 2: Naah, Maud the Withered.
YOKEL 1: Oh. Her.
(ALOUD, ADDRESSING CROWD) Hear me, men of Stockbridge! Hear me!
YOKEL 2: We hears you!
Good. Good. I am Hubert, Earl of Mummerset. Your master!
YOKEL 3: (HECKLING) Who says?
YOKELS 1 & 2: Maud says.
YOKEL 3: What, Maud the Strumpet?
YOKELS 1 & 2: Naah, Maud the Withered.
YOKEL 3: Oh. Her.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 20
Men of Stockbridge, please!
YOKEL 2: Prove it!
I’m sorry?
YOKEL 2: Prove you are who you says you are!
Why, did not the Earl’s only son depart for the Holy Land some seven years past?
YOKEL 1: I dunno, did he?
(FX: DURING THE FOLLOWING SPEECH, WE SWITCH PERSPECTIVE UNTIL WE ARE WITH HUBERT. THE CROWD ARE NOW THE ONES IN THE BACKGROUND )
Quiet! And did not that only son take his father’s sword to Palestine? (FX: UNSHEATHING SWORD) See, here — I bear that sword! (MUSIC: STING) Volund’s Spear!
BEAT
YOKEL 2: Prove it!
Vexatious yokel, whatever do you mean?
YOKEL 2: What I says. Could be any old sword, that. Could be Volund’s Spike, for all as we know.
YOKEL 1: Heh. Volund’s Shard.
YOKEL 2: Volund’s Stump!
FX: CROWD FALL ABOUT. THEY’RE EASILY AMUSED
The sword is its own proof! It’s written here on the hilt — Volund’s Spear! See?
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
YOKEL 1: That’s in runes!
Well, yes. Volund was a Norseman, as is well-known.
YOKEL 2: Do you read runes?
Well, no.
YOKEL 2: (ALOUD) Anyone here read runes?
FX: CROWD NAYS
(SHOUTING TO BE HEARD) Well, if you don’t believe me — you won't believe in the wealth I bring my bondsmen?
YOKEL 1: Is it gold?
Better than that.
FX: CROWD GROANS
Why won’t you listen to me? Land. (FX: CROWD QUIETENS) I will give one hundred acres of land to anyone willing to rid my castle of its demons!
YOKEL 1: One hundred acres?
You heard.
YOKEL 2: Not bog land?
Woodland.
YOKEL 1: Yeah, but — demons?
YOKEL 2: Who says there’s demons?
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 22
(BARGING THROUGH) I says there’s demons!
(FX: CROWD GROANS. MAUD MOUNTS THE LITTLE STAGE FROM WHICH HUBERT HAS BEEN ADDRESSING THE CROWD AND STANDS NEXT TO HIM)

Ohh, you all know there’s demons! Demons and devils, squatting in Stockbridge Castle. You’ve seen the lightning in the High Keep! Choked on the infernal mists that wreathe our village! Heard their dragon’s roar echo all around the valley.
YOKEL 1: No bother to us, though, is they?
YOKEL 2: Keeps themselves to themselves.
FX: CROWD AGREEMENT
You cowardly rabble!

(INTERRUPTING; ADDRESSING MAUD) Yes, thank you, Maud the Withered. (TO THE CROWD) Men. My bondsmen. If none among you has the heart to aid me, I ask this — send word! Send word that Hubert, Earl of Mummerset will give one hundred acres of woodland to any man able to expel his demons!
Send word, so the curse may be lifted! Send word!!!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 9: EXT. TURK’S HEAD
Time Lord! (SLASHING) You will die!!!
Doctor, he’s possessed!
FX: WITH A ROAR THE DRAGON SLASHES THROUGH SOME STAGE SCENERY
Nyssa, stay back!
(STOPPING) Nyssa. This is Nyssa of Traken?
I am. You know me, then?
(FALTERING) I — I know that I must —
Lower those claws?
I must —
(VERY COMMANDING) Do as the Lord of Time commands!
(HE DOES SO) My Lady.
(SOTTO) Fascinating. A memetic confluence!
YOKEL 1: (DESCENDANT OF) What’s the matter, Mr Dragon? Fire gone from your belly?
FX: TITTERS FROM THE CROWD
Men of Stockbridge! Hear me! The performance is at an end!
BOOS
YOKEL 1: Just as things were starting to get interesting!
FX: AS CROWD DISPERSES:
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 24
(SOTTO) Memetic? What have memes got to do with it?
(SOTTO) It’s seems my — our — being here has caused this poor fellow to recall our meeting his own ancestor, in the dim and distant past.
(SOTTO) But that shouldn’t happen!
(SOTTO) Not ordinarily, no. Help me with his mask. (DRAGON MASK REMOVED; HIS VOICE IS LESS MUFFLED FROM NOW ON) There! That’s better, isn’t it, er —
Edward.
(THICKER ACCENT) Edward? My name’s not Edward!
It isn’t?
Osbert, that’s my name. Peasant of Mummerset, that’s me!
Peasant?
I knows my place, my Lady. And I’d rather be a peasant than a serf.
(CALLING OVER) Father Christmas, how’s Saint George?
(OFF) His helmet took all of the blow. He’1ll have a nasty bump, that’s all.
Good, good.
(TO DRAGON) So what brought you to Stockbridge, Osbert?
Why, the demons, my lady!
Now, Osbert. You know there’s no such thing as demons.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 25
Yurr, that’s what I thought. But I was wrong. There was demons. In the castle. In the keep. Just like she said.
Who said?
Maud, of course. Not Maud the Strumpet, mind. Maud the Withered!
3: Oh. Her.
Tell me, Osbert — what year is it?
Why, the year that the Ant by the Lion was slain!
Oh dear.
No, no, I’m beginning to understand. And what day, Osbert?
The third after Whitsun. The day that Hubert, Earl of Mummerset returned from Palestine. My Lord. (SWOONS)
(CATCHING HIM — EFFORT) It’s alright, we’ve got you. Osbert?
(COMING OVER) Here, he’s right out of it now!
A good sleep, that’s all he needs. He’1ll be right as rain once we’ve gone. Nyssa and I, that is.
At last. The twenty-first century, please.
. the twelfth century, actually.
The twelfth century.
1199, to be precise. The year that the Ant by the Lion was slain. Come on, Nyssa. Time we left exited stage right.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 26
SCENE 10: EXT. CASTLE GATE
FX: TARDIS MATERIALISES. DOORS OPEN
(WALKING OUT) .. The Ant, that’s Saladin. And the Lion — well, that’s Richard the Lionheart, King of all England.
(FX: CLOSING DOOR) Don’t tell me. You knew him personally.
A long time ago, [yes] — (REACTING) Oh.
The stone fortress — that’d be Stockbridge Castle, I take it?
I presume so. It’s all ruins now. (CORRECTING HIMSELF) Then.
And the crowd of heavily armed medieval types with their jaws hanging open would be...?
Friendly. I hope. (ALOUD) Hello! Please, don’t be alarmed. I’m the Doctor, this is Nyssa.
We’re travellers. From a far-distant realm!
(FX: TEN FEET OFF) Travellers. With a strange blue cart.
. They’re demons! Demons, I tell you!
Who said that?
I said it. Maud said it!
Would that be Maud the Strumpet, or Maud the Withered?
FX: CROWD GASPS
You knows me?
Only by reputation.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 27
Nyssa, please.
I’m making things worse, aren’t I?
Rather. (ALOUD) Now — I realise my cart is somewhat unorthodox, but I assure you it’s all the rage in the Levant.
Is that so?

HUBERT: Well, yes. Volund was a Norseman, as is well-known.
HUBERT: YOKEL 2: Do you read runes?
HUBERT: Well, no.
HUBERT: YOKEL 2: (ALOUD) Anyone here read runes?
HUBERT: (SHOUTING TO BE HEARD) Well, if you don’t believe me — you won't believe in the wealth I bring my bondsmen?
HUBERT: YOKEL 1: Is it gold?
HUBERT: Better than that.
HUBERT: Why won’t you listen to me? Land. (FX: CROWD QUIETENS) I will give one hundred acres of land to anyone willing to rid my castle of its demons!
HUBERT: YOKEL 1: One hundred acres?
HUBERT: You heard.
HUBERT: YOKEL 2: Not bog land?
HUBERT: Woodland.
HUBERT: YOKEL 1: Yeah, but — demons?
HUBERT: YOKEL 2: Who says there’s demons?
HUBERT: 21
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 22
MAUD: (BARGING THROUGH) I says there’s demons!
MAUD: (FX: CROWD GROANS. MAUD MOUNTS THE LITTLE STAGE FROM WHICH HUBERT HAS BEEN ADDRESSING THE CROWD AND STANDS NEXT TO HIM)
MAUD: Ohh, you all know there’s demons! Demons and devils, squatting in Stockbridge Castle. You’ve seen the lightning in the High Keep! Choked on the infernal mists that wreathe our village! Heard their dragon’s roar echo all around the valley.
MAUD: YOKEL 1: No bother to us, though, is they?
MAUD: YOKEL 2: Keeps themselves to themselves.
MAUD: You cowardly rabble!
HUBERT: (INTERRUPTING; ADDRESSING MAUD) Yes, thank you, Maud the Withered. (TO THE CROWD) Men. My bondsmen. If none among you has the heart to aid me, I ask this — send word! Send word that Hubert, Earl of Mummerset will give one hundred acres of woodland to any man able to expel his demons!
MAUD: Send word, so the curse may be lifted! Send word!!!
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 23
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 9: EXT. TURK’S HEAD
DRAGON: Time Lord! (SLASHING) You will die!!!
NYSSA: Doctor, he’s possessed!
DOCTOR: Nyssa, stay back!
DRAGON: (STOPPING) Nyssa. This is Nyssa of Traken?
NYSSA: I am. You know me, then?
DRAGON: (FALTERING) I — I know that I must —
DOCTOR: Lower those claws?
DRAGON: I must —
NYSSA: (VERY COMMANDING) Do as the Lord of Time commands!
DRAGON: (HE DOES SO) My Lady.
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Fascinating. A memetic confluence!
DOCTOR: YOKEL 1: (DESCENDANT OF) What’s the matter, Mr Dragon? Fire gone from your belly?
FATHER CHRISTMAS: Men of Stockbridge! Hear me! The performance is at an end!
CROWD: YOKEL 1: Just as things were starting to get interesting!
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 24
NYSSA: (SOTTO) Memetic? What have memes got to do with it?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) It’s seems my — our — being here has caused this poor fellow to recall our meeting his own ancestor, in the dim and distant past.
NYSSA: (SOTTO) But that shouldn’t happen!
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Not ordinarily, no. Help me with his mask. (DRAGON MASK REMOVED; HIS VOICE IS LESS MUFFLED FROM NOW ON) There! That’s better, isn’t it, er —
NYSSA: Edward.
DRAGON: (THICKER ACCENT) Edward? My name’s not Edward!
DOCTOR: It isn’t?
DRAGON: Osbert, that’s my name. Peasant of Mummerset, that’s me!
NYSSA: Peasant?
DRAGON: I knows my place, my Lady. And I’d rather be a peasant than a serf.
DOCTOR: (CALLING OVER) Father Christmas, how’s Saint George?
FATHER CHRISTMAS: (OFF) His helmet took all of the blow. He’1ll have a nasty bump, that’s all.
DOCTOR: Good, good.
NYSSA: (TO DRAGON) So what brought you to Stockbridge, Osbert?
DRAGON: Why, the demons, my lady!
NYSSA: Now, Osbert. You know there’s no such thing as demons.
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 25
DRAGON: Yurr, that’s what I thought. But I was wrong. There was demons. In the castle. In the keep. Just like she said.
DOCTOR: Who said?
DRAGON: Maud, of course. Not Maud the Strumpet, mind. Maud the Withered!
NYSSA: 3: Oh. Her.
DOCTOR: Tell me, Osbert — what year is it?
DRAGON: Why, the year that the Ant by the Lion was slain!
NYSSA: Oh dear.
DOCTOR: No, no, I’m beginning to understand. And what day, Osbert?
DRAGON: The third after Whitsun. The day that Hubert, Earl of Mummerset returned from Palestine. My Lord. (SWOONS)
NYSSA: (CATCHING HIM — EFFORT) It’s alright, we’ve got you. Osbert?
FATHER CHRISTMAS: (COMING OVER) Here, he’s right out of it now!
DOCTOR: A good sleep, that’s all he needs. He’1ll be right as rain once we’ve gone. Nyssa and I, that is.
NYSSA: At last. The twenty-first century, please.
DOCTOR: . the twelfth century, actually.
NYSSA: The twelfth century.
DOCTOR: 1199, to be precise. The year that the Ant by the Lion was slain. Come on, Nyssa. Time we left exited stage right.
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 26
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 10: EXT. CASTLE GATE
DOCTOR: (WALKING OUT) .. The Ant, that’s Saladin. And the Lion — well, that’s Richard the Lionheart, King of all England.
NYSSA: (FX: CLOSING DOOR) Don’t tell me. You knew him personally.
DOCTOR: A long time ago, [yes] — (REACTING) Oh.
NYSSA: The stone fortress — that’d be Stockbridge Castle, I take it?
DOCTOR: I presume so. It’s all ruins now. (CORRECTING HIMSELF) Then.
NYSSA: And the crowd of heavily armed medieval types with their jaws hanging open would be...?
DOCTOR: Friendly. I hope. (ALOUD) Hello! Please, don’t be alarmed. I’m the Doctor, this is Nyssa.
NYSSA: We’re travellers. From a far-distant realm!
HUBERT: (FX: TEN FEET OFF) Travellers. With a strange blue cart.
MAUD: . They’re demons! Demons, I tell you!
NYSSA: Who said that?
MAUD: I said it. Maud said it!
NYSSA: Would that be Maud the Strumpet, or Maud the Withered?
MAUD: You knows me?
NYSSA: Only by reputation.
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 27
DOCTOR: Nyssa, please.
NYSSA: I’m making things worse, aren’t I?
DOCTOR: Rather. (ALOUD) Now — I realise my cart is somewhat unorthodox, but I assure you it’s all the rage in the Levant.
HUBERT: Is that so?
DOCTOR: I wonder, sire — by your finery — you wouldn’t be Hubert, Earl of Mummerset, by any chance?
HUBERT: I would. Fear not, Doctor, we Normans can easily tell a knight from a demon. Unlike this Saxon rabble!
HUBERT: YOKEL 1: Who’re you calling a rabble?
HUBERT: Quiet! (TO DOCTOR) I know why you’re here, Sir Doctor. And I wish you all the best, in your mission.
NYSSA: Mission?
HUBERT: Why, to rid my castle of its demons.
DOCTOR: I’m not sure I believe in demons, sire.
HUBERT: Neither did the fellow before you. I expect he’s changed his mind now, though.
NYSSA: 3: I don’t understand.
NYSSA: (FX: A DISTANT ELECTRICAL DISCHARGE — AS SUFFERED BY YAVUZ IN EARLIER SCENE)
MAUD: There! There, I saw lightning!
DOCTOR: Lightning?
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 28
MAUD: There! On the battlements!
HUBERT: Oh dear. Well, Sir Doctor: it would appear your chance will come very soon.
NYSSA: His chance to what?
OSBERT: (FX: FAR DISTANT — ON BATTLEMENTS) Please, no! Get away from me! No!
OSBERT: YOKEL 1: (LAUGHING) Good old Osbert!
OSBERT: YOKEL 2: (SHOUTING UP) Have you seen ‘em, Osbert? Have you seen the demons?
NYSSA: Osbert? Doctor!
DOCTOR: Yes, I heard.
OSBERT: (FROM ABOVE) Hear me, O Lord. I repent all (FX: A CRACKLE OF LIGHTNING; A SQUEAL FROM OSBERT) all my sins! You knows they’ve been many.
OSBERT: YOKEL 1: He’s going to jump!
OSBERT: YOKEL 2: I knew he’d be a jumper.
NYSSA: Osbert! Please, don’t!
OSBERT: Stealing my neighbour’s mud! (FX: A CRACKLE; A SQUEAL) Whistling on a Tuesday! O God in heaven, it’s coming!
NYSSA: No! Don’t jump. Doctor, we’ve got to-!!!
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 29
CROWD: NYSSA3: There’s water?
DOCTOR: A moat. A traditional feature of the medieval castle.
NYSSA: Well, why didn’t you say so?
HUBERT: Pull him out! Let his cowardice shame him for the rest of his miserable life!
HUBERT: (FX: IN THE BACKGROUND, WE HEAR A WET OSBERT BEING EXTRICATED FROM THE MOAT)
HUBERT: YOKEL 1: He’s always been a coward, has Osbert. Brand him, I say! Brand him like the others! Then he’1ll remember.
HUBERT: YOKEL 2: Yurr! Thieving beggar, he stole my mud!
HUBERT: So be it. Take him to the smithy.
DOCTOR: (WALKING OVER) There’s no call for any punishment!
HUBERTL: No call?
NYSSA: It won’t make him any braver, will it?
HUBERT: Your pageboy is right, noble Doctor. (CALLING OFF) Branding won’t teach this fellow a lesson.
HUBERT: Push him back in the moat and let him drown!
OSBERT: (OFF) What? But I-
OSBERT: (FX: OSBERT IS PUSHED BACK INTO THE MOAT WITH A SPLASH AND A PROTEST. CHEER FROM THE CROWD. )
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 30
DOCTOR WHO: NYSSA3: No!!! That’s barbaric!
HUBERT: ‘Tis only in jest, boy: he’ll be fished out and branded just like all the other failures. (CHANGING THE SUBJECT) Well, then. Doctor. I wish you all the best. You don’t look much like a fighter to me, so I fear my hundred acres shall remain unclaimed at cockcrow. But one never knows, does one?
DOCTOR: What hundred acres?
HUBERT: You men, let them through! They’re next!
NYSSA: Doctor, I don’t like the sound of this.
DOCTOR: My lord, I think you’ve mistaken me for someone else.
HUBERT: Don’t tell me you’ve got cold feet already? Are you so hungry for the burning badge of cowardice?
HUBERT: (FX: OSBERT HAS BEEN FISHED OUT AGAIN AND IS BEING DRAGGED UNWILLINGLY AWAY )
HUBERT: YOKEL 1: (FAR OFF) The smithy’s this way, Osbert Mud-Stealer!
OSBERT: (FAR OFF) Please! Please — don’t brand me! Noooooo!
HUBERT: Take up your sword, Doctor! Take your page! My demons await you both!
NYSSA: Doctor, don’t say you’re going into that castle?
DOCTOR: Right now, I don’t see any alternative. Do you?
MAUD: Doomed! Doomed! You’re doooo0c0c0ccomed!!! (INSANE CACKLE... INTO CLOSING THEME )
MAUD: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 3]

NO REPRISE
SCENE 11: INT. BLACKSMITHS’ SHED
FX: OSBERT BEING MANHANDLED IN BY 2 x YOKELS
Please, Jack, no! Not the branding iron!
YOKEL 2: You’s brought it on yerself, Osbert! Smithy — is your brand all hot and ready?
Aye, which one?
I gets a choice?
This one — (FX: HISS OF BRAND STAMPING DOWN ON WOOD) — this one’s me Poacher’s brand. With a ‘P’ for ‘Poacher’, see? Here — (FX: HISS OF BRAND STAMPING DOWN ON WOOD) — this here’s me
Apostate’s brand, with an ‘A’.
B-but I’m a coward!
Nah, I hasn’t got a ‘K’. I got an ‘R’. R’s a bit like a ‘K’.
YOKEL 1: What’s the ‘R’ for?
(FX: STOKING FIRE) Cattle rustlers.
YOKEL 2: He admitted to stealing my mud. I reckon that counts as rustling.
Right-o. The ‘Rustle brand’ it is, then. Hold him down, men!
YOKELS 1 & 2: Yurr!
(WRITHING, HELD DOWN) Please! No!!!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 32
(FX: HISS OF APPROACHING BRAND) Look, I can make this quick and agonising, or slow and agonising. Which do you think’s best?
(OFF, JUST OUTSIDE) Hold there, smithy!
(WALKING IN) If you wouldn’t mind.
It’s alright saying ‘hold’, my Lord Hubert, but me brand’1l be going cold.
Surely you have other irons in the fire?
(BEHIND) A whole alphabet, it looks like.
YOKEL 1: Yurr, except for a ‘K’.
Quite. Osbert, isn’t it?
That’s what they calls me.
Ask him, Sir Doctor. But be quick about it: you have an appointment to keep in the keep. (WITH A LITTLE LAUGH) I say, that’s rather good!
Hilarious.
Ask me what, Sir Doctor?
Osbert. I’m — well, I’m here to vanquish the demons.
(CHIDING) Doctor. You know there’s no such thing as demons.

Yurr, that’s what I thought. (FX: DUB OVER IDENTICAL DRAGON DIALOGUE FROM PREVIOUS EP — JUST A FAINT ECHO) But I was wrong. There was demons. In the castle. In the keep. Just like [she said —] (FX: FADE DUB)
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL)
. Just like Maud said...
Page 33
Quite. Now, Osbert, I think you saw something strange and
extraordinary inside that castle.
Oh no, sir. Just demons.
This is pointless.
(SHARPLY) Thank you, Nyssa. The thing is, Osbert — the Earl of
Mummerset here, he’s agreed to let you go unbranded,
YOKELS & SMITHY:
GROAN
if —
. if you’ll agree to join me on my Quest, and show me what it
was you saw in the castle?
I isn’t never going back there! Brand us, Smithy! Make it
quick!
(FX: HISS OF BRAND) Quick and agonising?
Yurr, whatever! Just get on with it!
Like you says.
Wait!
GROAN
Ungrateful wretch, I’ve given you a chance of redemption!
Redempt us all you like, there’s no power in heaven or Earth could compel me to step foot inside that castle of fear again!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 34
You don’t understand. The Doctor is a powerful knight, from far overseas. A friend of Sir Justin of Wells, in fact.
Sir Justin of Wells?
Did you know him?
(HURRIEDLY) Yes, yes, of course. Mighty Sir Justin.
He and I shared the same Quest, once.
And conquered the demon Mel, er —
Melanicus. Well, it was Sir Justin did most of the conquering. But, yes, I suppose we did.
Ah, now I know I’ve found my champion!
So — so you’ve done a bit of this demon-conquering before, Sir Doctor?
I have, yes.
On a regular basis.
Well, then — I’m in! On one condition.
You presume to set a condition?
If I runs away again, Smithy here brands us proper, with a ‘K’.
(SIGHS) Yes.
Don’t care who thinks I’m a coward, but I hasn’t been near no horses — right?
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 35
SCENE 12: EXT. CASTLE GATE (BY TARDIS)
FX: COCK CROWS
(FX: WALKING OVER MUD) Dawn! And a sweeter day for an exorcism I cannot imagine, Sir Doctor!
(FX: FOLLOWING) The, ah, demons are no less active by daylight?
(FX: FOLLOWING) Nurr, Stockbridge gets no brighter than dusk. Not these days.
(FX: FOLLOWING) Of course not — (FX: SQUELCHING IN DUNG) Eurgh!
(STOPPING, CONCERNED) What is it? Nyssa?
(EXCITED) That’s horse’s muck. That’s lucky, that is!
(DISTRACTED, TRYING TO WIPE SHOE ON GRASS) Not in these shoes it isn’t.
(MILDLY IRRITATED) Yes, yes. Osbert: what did you mean, ‘Stockbridge gets no brighter than dusk’?
Well, what I says.
I can’t account for Saxon superstition, Sir Doctor, but that part is true. This cursed village sits permanently in a foggy slough.
Interesting. And that would be since —
. Since the demons came, yurr.
(FX: RAPPING ON TARDIS DOOR) Here we are, Doctor. Your strange blue cart. Is this where you keep your arms?
In a manner of speaking.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 36
Arms'1ll do no good against demons. Relics, that’s what you need!
Relics?
Holy relics, my lady. Nunses’ collarbones. Monkses’ jaws. That sort of thing.
Clerical bodyparts won’t aid a noble knight in battle, you stupid peasant. Swords, spears and spikenets, that’s what Sir Doctor is fetching.
Actually, I was thinking more of —
(SOTTO) Come on, Doctor. Can’t we just go?
(SOTTO) We can’t.
(TO OSBERT) There’s a damn fearsome armoury Sir Doctor keeps in his blue cart, I’1l be bound. Pikestaffs! Quarterstaffs! .. All
sorts of, er, staffs.
(SOTTO) But I thought that’s why —
(SOTTO) .. we were headed back to the TARDIS? No.
(SOTTO) Then why?
(SOTTO) Whatever’s inside that castle, I’ve no intention of meeting it at the front door.
Dun’t matter whichever staffs you picks. It’s relics he wants. Relics, I tells you!
THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA SPEAK OVER THE NEXT TWO SPEECHES
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 37
Really, the superstition of the peasantry gets worse and worse these days. Relics indeed! Next you’1ll be telling me we ought to consult a wise woman!
Maud the Withered’s a wise woman and she’s always worth listening to...
(SOTTO) Wells Wood is just a few hundred yards away. You’1l have to make a dash for it. And take Osbert with you.
(SOTTO) Osbert! But-
(SOTTO) I won’t stand by while a man is branded.
(SOTTO) Of course, sorry. And then — what? We find the back door to the castle?
(SOTTO) Something like that. Continue our investigations without this ‘England for the Normans’ idiot breathing down our necks.
Come on, Sir Doctor.
(ALOUD, DECISIVELY) My page. Take this craven peasant around the rearside of my cart and fetch me my sword.
What, both of us for one sword?
(ALOUD) And... my shield!
Must be a blummen’ mighty shield.
Follow me, peasant! (FX: SHE AND OSBERT WALK AROUND THE REAR OF THE TARDIS)

CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 38
I prefer to fight unencumbered.

(CALLING OUT) Oh, and — page! Bring me my spear of burning gold! Bring me my, er, chariot of fire!
That’s more like it!
Isn’t it. If you’ll excuse me, sire — I’1l just see what’s taking them so long? (EXITS)

Yes, of course. (CALLING AFTER) I trust you beat that page of yours good and often? Nightly after supper, that’s best... (BEAT; TO SELF) Yes, a spear of burning gold, that’s the business. A chariot of fire — (BEAT) I wonder what he means by ‘burning gold’? I say, Sir Doctor... (FX: HE MOVES ROUND THE BACK OF THE TARDIS) Sir Doctor? Sir D— (SPOTS THE THREE OF THEM LEGGING IT INTO WELLS WOOD) Oi! You can’t just run away!
(FX: DISTANT) (CALLING) Very sorry, sire — but this is a doomed quest! We’re off after the Holy Grail instead! (TO NYSSA & OSBERT) Nyssa, Osbert — Run! (RUNS)
(ALOUD) Come back! You craven knight! Come back right this instant!

SCENE 13: EXT. WELLS WOOD (TRAP SITE)
FX: DOCTOR, OSBERT & NYSSA RUSHING THROUGH UNDERGROWTH
(RUNNING) I doesn’t know what you two is making so much fuss about. It’s only a coward’s brand.
(STOPPING, CATCHING BREATH) ‘Only’?
(CATCHING BREATH) Yeah. Just make sure they don’t spell nothing. I heard about a fellow over in the next valley who collected brands for thieving, witchcraft, indecency —
(STOPPING, TURNING) Will you two please hurry along? I daresay the Earl will have got some sort of posse together by now.
Yurr. With pitchforks and that.
Quite. So I strongly suggest we put a little more distance between ourselves and the village, before we even begin to think of heading back.
(TO OSBERT) How much further is it to the river?
Mile or two east, I’d say.
Excellent idea, Nyssa! We’1ll walk the river a while, that way they won’t be able to follow our footsteps!
Yes, and I’1l be able to clean my shoes.
That’s settled, then. (FX: TURNING, STRIDING OFF) Osbert, Nyssa — best foot forw[ard-] (FALLING)
(FX: SIMULTANEOUSLY, A CRACK! AS THE GROUND GIVES WAY BENEATH HIS FEET — HE’S WALKED OVER A PIT TRAP, LAID OVER WITH REEDS. THUMPS ONTO GROUND TEN FEET BELOW)
(RUSHING TO EDGE OF PIT) Doctor!!!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 40
Boar trap, that is. You want to mind that.
(BELOW, WINDED, CALLING UP) Yes, thank you, Osbert. A little late, but thank you all the same.
(CALLING DOWN) Doctor, are you injured?
I seem to have torn my coat. (SCRAMBLING TO FEET) But not injured, no.
Well, that’s a relief.

(FX: FAILING TO SCRAMBLE UP SIDES OF PIT — SODDEN EARTH GIVING WAY) Actually, I’m rather fond of this coat. But still, nothing a needle and thread won’t cure — (GIVING UP) Oh, this is hopeless! The ground’s so sodden it’s giving way when I try to gain a hold.
That’1ll be the fog we’ve been having.
FX: INTERRUPTING, OFF, SNORT OF WILD BOAR
NYSSA3: Quiet! I heard something.
I din’t hear nothing. Mind you, me ears is still full of water from the moat.
The Earl’s posse, I daresay.
No, no. More like —
FX: ANOTHER WILD BOAR SNORT, OFF. PERHAPS PAWING GROUND
There! There it is again. Like — oh, I don’t know. An animal.
It weren’t a sound like — (IMITATES WILD BOAR SNORT)
Yes, that’s it exactly! (IMITATES WILD BOAR SNORT)
FX: ANSWERED BY A MORE MENACING WILD BOAR SNORT, CLOSER TO
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL)
Ohhh.
Why, what is it?
Page
I hate to be obvious, but if this is a boar trap —
It is.
. there must be wild boars in the woods.
Mummerset Blacks, yurr.

Pigs with tusks.
Angry pigs, and all.
Nyssa, take Osbert and get away from here.
We can’t just leave you!
I’1l1 follow on as best I can. Just — go!!!
(FX: CHORUS OF SIX OR SO BOAR SNORTS, GETTING
They’re getting closer!

You’re not wrong, Osbert.
After three, sir?
FX: THE BOARS CHARGE, BREAKING UNDERGROWTH
Three!!!

CLOSER)

SCENE 14: EXT. WELLS WOOD (DEEP FOREST)
(FX: NYSSA AND OSBERT FLEEING 6 x HEAVILY SNORTING WILD BOARS — CRASHING THROUGH UNDERGROWTH )
(RUNNING) Hurry, lad! The river! We got to clean your shoes!
(RUNNING) That’s the least of our worries right now. They’re gaining on us!
(RUNNING) You don’t understand. The horse’s muck’s in their nostrils! They think’s you’re a gelding! Mummerset Blacks, they’1l bring down anything!

(RUNNING) That’s what I’m saying!

(RUNNING TO HALT) What you doing? They’1l have us any moment.
(REMOVING SHOE) Correction. They’1ll have my shoe. (THROWING SHOE) Here, piggy piggies!
(FX: FRENZIED SNORTS AS THE BOARS CHANGE DIRECTION, FOLLOWING SHOE. EXCITED SNORTS AS THEY FIGHT OVER IT, RUNNING OVER: )
(CATCHING BREATH) Yurr, isn’t you clever for a page!
I am not a page. I am Nyssa of Traken! (CALLING AFTER PIGS) Here, you might as well have the other. (THROWS OTHER SHOE)
What — a Lady in britches?
It’s all the rage in the Levant. Come on. (MOVING OFF)
(FOLLOWING) Where’s we going now?
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 43
Back to the boar trap. (FX: TREADING ON BRAMBLES) Ow! Owww!
Yurr, you doesn’t want to go treading on brambles, my Lady. Specially not in bare feet.
Ohh, I hate the twelfth century!
Piggyback?
(ALARMED) Where?
(PATTING OWN BACK) Here, my Lady. Hop on!
Oh. Oh, I see. (MOUNTING OSBERT) Thank you, Osbert.
My pleasure, my Lady. (FX: BEGINS TO MOVE OFF) Mind your feet in my face, though. They still stinks a bit. No more’n most peasants’ feet, mind. (LAUGHS)
(LAUGHING) Well, only if you’re sure.
(FX: AS BEFORE, DUB OVER FAINT ECHO OF IDENTICAL DIALOGUE FROM
I knows my place, my Lady. And I’d rather be a peasant than a serf.
What’s the [difference-?] (FX: CUT DUB) What’s the... (NYSSA TRAILS OFF, HAVING A DEJA VU MOMENT).
My lady?
I just thought... Those words. I’ve heard them before... (SNAPPING OUT OF IT) Never mind. Come on. We’d best get back to the Doctor.
FX: FADE AS THEY MOVE AWAY
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 44
SCENE 15: EXT. WELLS WOOD (TRAP SITE)
FX: SOMEONE APPROACHING TRAP THROUGH UNDERGROWTH
(IN PIT, CALLING OUT) Nyssa? Nyssa, is that you?
(STOPPING, PEERING DOWN) Ho, what’s this? A boar in his trap?
Maud the Withered. I’m not a boar.

ROLAND: (RANTING) Is it any wonder, my Lady, that demons gather in such a place? A place of bribery and corruption, where demonic infestation may only be rooted out by auction!
HUBERT: Well, I wouldn’t put it quite that way myself.
ROLAND: Luckily, sire, we are true and noble knights. Paladins, successors to the Peers of the Emperor Charlemagne himself!
SMITHY: Oh, he’s that Roland of Brittany.
HUBERT: You’ve heard of him, Smithy?
SMITHY: Yurr. The Song of Roland, that’s a great one with the minstrels.
HUBERT: Well, I’ve never heard it.
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 57
SMITHY: (TO ROLAND) So you’d be direct in line from the Roland who made his final stand against heathen forces at the Battle of Roncevaux Pass?
ROLAND: I would. My comrades likewise — Samson, Engelier and Ganelon!
SMITHY: Cor!
HUBERT: What’re you fawning over him for? I thought he killed Jasper!
SMITHY: Yurr, but that’s afore I knew he was famous.
NYSSA: (PIPING UP) Well then, Sir Roland, hadn’t you and your knights better get on your heroic quest?
ROLAND: We shall, Nyssa of Traken, we shall. But first, Lord Hubert, there is the matter of our expenses.
HUBERT: E-expenses?
ROLAND: Saddlery. Armoury. Weaponry. General administrative costs. It all adds up — does it not, my knights?
NYSSA: (CYNICAL) Oh yes. Adds up to what?
ROLAND: Four thousand gold pieces.
HUBERT: I don’t have that!
ROLAND: What, you flinch at the cost of ridding your castle of demons?
HUBERT: I-it’s not that.
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 58
ROLAND: Ah, but perhaps we have got it wrong. Perhaps a man could only suffer such a visitation if he was possessed by demons himself! Perhaps we should begin, sire, by purging you?
HUBERT: M-me?
ROLAND: By fire. Is the best way. (CALLING OFF) Samson, fetch brushwood! Engelier, Ganelon — build a stakes!
HUBERT: No, no — wait. I do not have coffers, sir Knight. But I may yet extract an added tithe from my peasantry.
SMITHY: Not another tithe!
HUBERT: Shut up, serf. (TO ROLAND) Say — four hundred gold pieces a year, payable over ten years?
ROLAND: (SNIFFS) Five hundred over the same period. That is acceptable.
ROLAND: 3 x KNIGHTS:
HUBERT: Five hundred? But you said —
NYSSA: It’s called ‘interest’, sire. It’s very modern.
HUBERT: Very well. The castle gate’s that way.
ROLAND: Well then — move!
HUBERT: Oh no, you’re the experts. Best you just get on with it.
ROLAND: . and you know the Castle buildings, inside and out. You’re coming with us.
HUBERT: N-no.
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
ROLAND: Engelier, Ganelon — mace!!!
HUBERT: Oh, alright then. But the so-called Lady comes too!
NYSSA: I don’t think so!
ROLAND: It is true, demons may be drawn to such a paragon. And once drawn out of the shadows, we may smite them!
NYSSA: This is ridiculous!
ROLAND: Samson, hold her!
OSBERT: (ARRIVING) Making friends already, my Lady? Did I miss much?
HUBERT: Ah! The cowardly yokel! He’s met the demons, he’d be useful. Osbert, isn’t it?
ROLAND: Ganelon — seize him.
OSBERT: Oi! I just came back for my branding, that’s all!
NYSSA: (SOTTO) What are you playing at, Lord Hubert?
HUBERT: (SOTTO) The more bodies in the Castle, my ‘Lady’, the less chance I have of falling victim to the demons. Safety in numbers!
NYSSA: (SOTTO) It’s not Osbert who should be branded for cowardice —
NYSSA: it’s you!
ROLAND: (FX: MOUNTING HORSE) Onward! On! The Quest begins!
ROLAND: 59
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 60
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 22: INT. CASTLE CELLARS
MAUD: (OFF) Put something more into it. S’only a storm drain. Sir Runt!
DOCTOR: (OFF, EFFORT) I am not a — (FX: STORM DRAIN SHIFTS) .. runt!
DOCTOR: (EMERGING FROM DRAIN) There. Now, where are we? Some sort of — dungeon?
MAUD: (OFF, CLAMBERING UP. DERISIVELY) Dungeon! Kitchens, this is! Why else you think they got wine barrels in here, eh? Now, give us your hand.
DOCTOR: (HELPING MAUD OUT, EFFORT) There. (BRUSHING HIS HANDS) Wine barrels, yes. And an oven, I see. (TRIES FINGER — SNATCHES IT BACK) Ah! Still warm.
MAUD: Mmm, elderberries. (SMACKS LIPS) Nice. Reminds me of mother.
MAUD: (FX: AS MAUD STIRS, SOMETHING BOBS UP IN BARREL, BREAKING THE SURFACE )
DOCTOR: (RUSHING OVER) Maud? What is it?
MAUD: (WHIMPERING) There’s someone — someone in the wine.
DOCTOR: Yes. Dead some time, by the looks of it.
MAUD: Here, I knows him! I knows his face! ‘Tis the heathen fellow!
DOCTOR: Sorry?
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 6]
MAUD: Yavuz, that’s him. The young Earl’s man. The Turkish Knight!
DOCTOR: Did you say ‘Turkish Knight’?
DOCTOR: (FX: DUB OVER FAINT ECHO OF DOCTOR AND NYSSA, AT END OF SC. 3,
SAYING: ‘A Turkish Knight!’ THEN CUT DEAD)
MAUD: (SQUEAKS) He blinked! Heaven help me, he blinked!
DOCTOR: There’s no life in him, Maud. Trust me.
DOCTOR: Well, there wasn’t.
MAUD: A revenant! Save us, Sir Doctor! Save us!
DOCTOR: I suggest you take a step backwards, Maud.
MAUD: Why? You going to kill it?
DOCTOR: Him, Maud, him. And no, I’m not going to kill him: I’m going to talk to him. (CLEARS THROAT) Hello, Yavuz. I’m the Doctor.
YAVUZ: Experimental subject seven. Experiment — resistance to drowning. Subject endures.
MAUD: There’s another! In the oven!
DOCTOR: What?
DOCTOR: YAVUZ 2: (STEPPING OUT OF OVEN) Experimental subject five. Experiment — resistance to slow heat exposure. Subject endures.
MAUD: They’re the same! Both of em, the same!
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 62
DOCTOR: Well, one’s looking rather more burnt than the other, but — yes, it would appear so. (TO YAVUZ 2:) Who are you? What are you doing here?
MAUD: I ain’t staying here to listen to you talking to these demons! I’m leaving. (FX: OPENS CREAKING DOOR) The courtyard’s up here.
MAUD: YAVUZ 1: Experiment interrupted. Experimental supervisor alerted and in transit.
DOCTOR: Maud! Not so fast. I don’t think these two are the only ones here.
MAUD: Think what you like, I’m getting out of here.
MAUD: (FX: SHE FLINGS OPEN THE DOOR TO BE MET BY A DISCHARGE OF ELECTRICAL ENERGY... AS SUFFERED BY YAVUZ IN PART ONE. OFF, MAUD SCREAMS, DIES)
DOCTOR: Maud! (STRIDES TOWARDS DOORWAY )
DOCTOR: (FX: FIZZING, CRACKLING SOUND APPROACHING: A RUTAN BOBBING THROUGH DOOR, IN FACT)
DOCTOR: YAVUZ 2: Supervisor approaching.
DOCTOR: Yes, so I see.
DOCTOR: So. You’re the demon of Stockbridge Castle, are you?
DOCTOR: Yes, I’d sooner you kept those tendrils away, if you don’t mind. I know what they can do.
RUTAN: You know our kind?
DOCTOR: Oh, I’ve met your kind before. I name you, ‘demon’. I name you — Rutan!
DOCTOR: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR WHO: CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 63

elements.text: PART THREE
INT. CASTLE CELLARS
FX: FIZZING LOUDER, HOVERING BESIDE THE DOCTOR
So. The demon of Stockbridge Castle, is it?
FX: FLICKERING OF CHARGED TENTACLES
Yes, I’d sooner you kept those tendrils away, if you don’t mind. I know what they can do.
You know our kind?
Oh, I’ve met your kind before. I name you, ‘demon’. I name you — Rutan!
SCENE CONTINUES:
SCENE 23: INT. CASTLE CELLARS
(FX: ANXIOUS TENTACLES) Then... you must not be of this Earth — not human!
No, I suppose I mustn’t.
Experimental subject seven — restrain this alien!
YAVUZ 1: (SHUFFLING FORWARD) Yes, drone leader.
Why so agitated, Rutan? (HIS ARM PINNED BACK BY YAVUZ 1) Aaah! Do I scare you?
A drone leader of the mighty Rutan Empire does not scare!
(PAINED) Then why get your clones to restrain me? (BEAT; REALISATION) Clones. Why clones? Metamorphosis: that’s the Rutan way, isn’t it?
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 64
Subject five — reseal heat source!
YAVUZ 2: (FX: SHUFFLING TO CLOSE OVEN DOOR) Yes, drone leader.
The oven. Yes, I remember now. Coming from an ice world, you’ve no tolerance for heat. That explains the mist! You concocted it in order to lower the local temperature!
You have encountered our kind before!
Oh yes. Your mortal enemies, too. The Sontarans!
(SPARKING) Genetically degenerate space trolls who dare challenge the might of the Rutan Empire!
Careful, you’re sparking. I suppose that’s the Rutan equivalent of frothing at the mouth. (A SUDDEN THOUGHT) Oh, so that’s what you’re doing here!
I do not understand.
The West Country? End of the twelfth century? You’re on the trail of the Sontarans, aren’t you? Well, of one Sontaran in particular. Commander Jingo Linx!
(A BIT PANICKY) A Commander of the Sontaran Space Fleet — is in this region?!?
You don’t mean you didn’t know?
BABBLE SUDDENLY, AS IF SPEAKING IN TONGUES
I say, are your clones quite alright?
Report. Report!!!
YAVUZ 1: There is — renewed activity.
YAVUZ 2: At the castle gate.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 65
SCENE 24: EXT. CASTLE GATE
FX: CHAINS DRAGGED OFF
Engelier, Samson — ready the horses! We use chains to drag down the portcullis!
FX: 2 x KNIGHTS CLANK OFF, CARRYING CHAINS. WHINNYING OFF
Is that wise, Roland of Brittany?
Ah. Fear not, Nyssa of Traken — these are mighty warhorses, not the feeble geldings native to this country. They can take the strain!
What I meant was, has it occurred to you that rather than keeping us out, the portcullis might be keeping the demons in?
You believe in the demons, then?
I wasn’t talking to you, Hubert.
I seen ‘em, I tells you. Pulsating with emerald fire, with flails of lightning!
Or you, Osbert!
Sorry, my Lady. Sorry!
And how precisely might a portcullis keep a demon in? (FX: PORTCULLIS RAISING OFF) Wait! Wait until I give the order!
Sir Roland: I don’t think your men are responsible for the portcullis. It seems to be opening of its own accord!
Release the horses! It is raising from the inside!
By some... Supernatural agency. (CROSSING HIMSELF) Oh, God in Heaven!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 66
NYSSA3: You realise what this means?
Why, that we may ride through, and vanquish these demons! (CALLING TO KNIGHTS) Onward! On!!!
3 x ROARS OF ASSENT
(SHOUTING TO MAKE HERSELF HEARD) No, it doesn’t! It means — Oh, what’s the use?
Means them demons knows we’s coming!
SCENE 25: INT. CASTLE CELLARS
BABBLING
(TO YAVUZES) Inform your clone-kin to draw the knights into the courtyard!
BEGIN BABBLING AGAIN
Is that wise, drone leader? What if these knights come en masse?
(CRACKLING) Then they shall be destroyed together!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 67
SCENE 26: EXT. CASTLE COURTYARD
FX: 4 x HORSES CLOPPING IN ON COBBLES
(FX: REINING IN HORSE) Whoa! (FX: OTHERS STOP) My Lord Hubert: what is it, there? On the cobbles?
Can’t see. This infernal fog!
(TO HIMSELF) Infernal indeed. (TO HUBERT) Well go and look, man!
FX: HUBERT STEPS ACROSS THE COBBLES
Saint George preserve us! ‘Tis my failed knights. All fallen.
What, this whole score of them?
FX: ANXIOUS HORSES
(FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE COURTYARD) There’s more over here. Another dozen maybe. (FX: CLATTER OF ARMOUR — EXAMINING BODIES) One moment.
Ghoulish Lady — leave them to rot!
That’s just it, Roland of Brittany. They’re not rotten.
(WALKING FORWARD) They’re cinders!
Yes, Osbert. (FX: POURING ASH OUT OF KNIGHT’S HELMET) (COUGHS) Turned to ashes. (THOUGHTFUL, TO SELF) Inside their armour...
(FX: DISMOUNTING, ALONG WITH OTHER KNIGHTS) So, Earl of Mummerset — which way into the High Keep?
The fog is thicker here than outside, how should I know?
Because you were born here, and raised here.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 68
Oh, I see. Yes. Well, I’ve not been back for seven years.
Pathetic. Samson, give Earl Hubert his sword. Dullard’s Spike or whatever he calls it.
FX: KNIGHT STEPS FORWARD
Volund’s Spear actually! But why?
Because you will lead the way.
Into the Keep?
But that’s where I saw it: the demon!
I don’t think that’s very wise, Sir Roland. I think we should get out of this place as soon as possible.
FX: CLANG OF PORTCULLIS SHUTTING BEHIND. ALARM FROM KNIGHTS
FX: RUNNING BACK) The portcullis! (FX: SHAKING PORTCULLIS
It’s no good. It’s shut tight.
It seems the decision to leave has been taken out of our hands! Proceed, sire!
Oh, m-mercy!
Why do you cower? Announce your presence! (FX: HE DRAWS HIS SWORD ON HUBERT) Do it!
(ALOUD) D-D-Demons! I am H-Hubert, Sixth Earl of Mummerset! I have come to take this castle back! (BEAT; SILENCE) There: the place must be deserted, let’s see if we can [get the]-
YAVUZ 3 [A RUTAN]: (OFF) You may not leave.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 69
Wh-who said that?
There! Beside the well!
Yavuz? Old friend?
Careful, Sir Hubert!
But — this is Yavuz! My old comrade from the Holy Land!
A heathen devil!
A Turkish Knight!
Yurr, but I bet he was a devil with that scimitar!
(REALISATION) A Turkish Knight! Like it was in the play. (FX: DUB OVER FAINT ECHO OF IDENTICAL DIALOGUE FROM PART ONE) “Here come I, the Turkish Knight, Come from the Turkish land to fight!”

But this is one man! We knights are four! (ALOUD) (FX: DUB OVER FAINT ECHO OF IDENTICAL DIALOGUE FROM PART ONE) Where is the Turk that will before me stand? I shall cut him down with my courageous hand!
YAVUZ 3: (FX: SHINK OF SCIMITAR) Drones — present your arms!
(FX: OTHER YAVUZES — THESE ALL RUTAN CLONES — CALLING FROM ABOVE, RIGHT AND LEFT)
YAVUZ 4: (FX: SHINK) Present arms!
YAVUZ 5: (FX: SHINK) Present arms!
YAVUZ 6: (FX: SHINK) Present arms!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL)
YAVUZ 7: (FX: SHINK) Present arms!
More of them! To the left, and the right!
Yurr, and up on high!
They’re identical!
Yavuz?
SCENE 27: INT. PASSAGE/DUNGEON
FX: RUTAN LEADING THE WAY, BOBBING ALONG, CRACKLING
Drones — bring the alien!
(TOGETHER) Drone leader.
What about Maud?
YAVUZ 1: The woman is dead.
Page
Then let her rest in peace. Grant her a proper burial — ah! (GRABBED TO EITHER SIDE, DRAGGED ALONG) Drone leader. Drone
leader!!!
(PAUSING, TURNING) What is it, alien?
You're too late. For the Sontaran. For Linx. He was destroyed when his castle blew up. Well, I say Irongron’s castle, in fact. Come to think of it,
Irongron’s.
(RESUMING, IRRITATED) Bring him!!!
castle — it was it wasn’t even
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 7]
(DRAGGED) .. but the point is, neither of you have any business here on Earth.
It is clear, the enemy has followed us here.
Linx was following you-? Then — what business do you have here? The Rutan Empire, I mean. Around now, you’re supposed to be retreating from the Mutters Spiral!
(ANGRY CRACKLES) The Rutan Empire does not retreat! We withdraw!

Fine! But you have no business with humankind, certainly at this stage of their development! Right now, they’re barely civilised. Little further advanced than hunting, gathering and battering one another with clubs.
(STOPS) They are suitable for our great purpose. Bring him through!
Oh, so it’s the dungeon, is it? I knew there’d be one around here someplace. (FX: DOCTOR DRAGGED DOWN THREE STEPS INTO DUNGEON) I’m coming, I’m coming!
Place him in the tensile resistance device.
It’s called a ‘rack’. It’s an instrument of torture, not an experimental [device —] (PENNY DROPS) Oh. I’m beginning to understand.
YAVUZ 1: Lie down!
(LYING DOWN ON RACK) Experiments on clones, yes. Human clones. Listen, I know exactly what it is you’re up to here and I have to say you’re playing with fire!
Secure his limbs!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 72

(WHILE LEGS ARE BEING STRAPPED) (FX: BUCKLES) You want to beat the Sontarans at their own game, don’t you? Cloning, that is. You Rutans can shape-shift, yes, but — being largely amorphous and jelly-like in structure — you can’t replicate yourselves,
nor can you maintain another form indefinitely — (WRISTS STRAPPED) (FX: BUCKLES) .. ow! Gently. That’s my Chinamen arm!
Your speculation is not required!

But — if you clone yourselves while in human form, you’1ll end up with armies of obedient cannon-fodder, ideally suited to hand-to-hand combat, to throw at the enemy! (BEAT) There. Am I right, or am I right?
Quiet! Alien: you will tell us all you know about Sontaran activity in this sector! The fate of the Rutan Empire depends on it!
But — I’ve told you everything. Freely!
Drones — turn the rack!
We... obey...
I’d really much rather you [didn’t] —
FX: TURNING OF CRANK. STRAPS TIGHTEN
GASPS
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 73
SCENE 28: EXT. CASTLE COURTYARD
YAVUZ 3: (FX: STEPPING FORWARD) Advance!
YAVUZES 4/5/6/7: (FX: STEPPING FORWARD) Advance!
Five Yavuzes! How can this be?
Easily. By androidisation, perhaps, or biogenetics? Cloning, even.
Yurr, that an’ wizardry!
Samson, Engelier, Ganelon — take arms! Send these witches’ sucklings back to Hell!
3 x KNIGHTS: (FX: CLOSING VISORS) Oui! /Oui!/Oui!
YAVUZ 3: Drones — attack!
YAVUZES 4/5/6/7: (FX: RUSHING FORWARD, HOLLERING) Attack!
(RUSHING FORWARD) Fight, mes braves! Like our forefathers did at Roncevaux, against the heathen horde — engage them!
3 x KNIGHTS: (RUSHING FORWARD, ROARING) Haaaarggh!
(FX: 4 x KNIGHTS’ SWORDS CLASH MEET SCIMITARS — CLANG! SPARKS! WHOMPF! 4 x KNIGHTS KNOCKED BACKWARDS BY ELECTRICAL ENERGY)
ROLAND/3 x KNIGHTS:
CRY OUT) (FX: CLATTERING TO FLOOR
(GASPING IN PAIN) What witchery is this, you demons?
Lightning! I told ye! I told ye!!!
(FX: GANELON IS STRUCK BY A SCIMITAR AND ELECTROCUTED. HE SCREAMS )
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 74
Ganelon! Ganelon!
Those scimitars are charged with electrical energy! And the Knights are wearing metal armour... (SHOUTING) Roland — retreat!
(DAZED) A Knight of Brittany does not retreat.
Yurr, but a peasant does! (LEGS IT)
I’m with you, yurr! I mean, yes — I mean — oh, never mind. Wait for me! (LEGS IT)
FX: IT IS ENGELIER’S TIME TO FRY. HE SCREAMS!
Engelier! No!
(SHOUTING) Your armour conducts their fire, Roland! That’s what happened to all those others! Reduced to ashes inside their suits.
I do not understand.
(RUSHING FORWARD) Take my hand! You must withdraw!
(FX: DRAGGED TO FEET) ‘Withdraw’?
(DRAGGING ROLAND) In heaven’s name, man!
YAVUZ 3: Drones — destroy this knight!
YAVUZ 4/5/6/7: We... obey!
(FX: 3 x SCIMITAR STRIKES AGAINST SAMSON’S METAL BREASTPLATE. ZZZAAKKK! FLAME THROUGH VISOR. SAMSON FRIED IN HIS OWN ARMOUR. SAMSON SCREAMS AND DIE, SLOWLY)
(RUNNING, WITH NYSSA) Samson! The bravest of my Knights!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page
(RUNNING) The last of your Knights!
YAVUZ 3: (OFF) Now the others! This knight and the female.
(SKIDDING TO A HALT) Still they come! I stand! I fight!
(STOPPING ALSO, TO GRAB HIM BY THE ARM) Not with swords, you don’t! Not with anything metal! Come on!
FX: THEY RUN AGAIN
(RUNNING) Then what?
(RUNNING) I don’t know. Something wooden. Quarterstaffs?
(RUNNING) Pah! You think a Knight of Brittany fights like a Saxon, with sticks?!?
YAVUZ 3: (OFF) Attack!!!
STRIDING FORWARD QUICKLY...
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 76
SCENE 29: INT. DUNGEON
Turn it, drones! Turn the rack!
FX: WHEEL TURNED. CREAKING OF RACK
GASPING, RECITING SHELLEY TO DISTRACT HIMSELF FROM THE PAIN
“As if a spectre, wrapped in shapeless terror,
Amid a company of ladies fair
Should glide and glow, till it became a mirror
Of all their beauty —”
Cease turning! (FX: RACK STOPS) What is this spiel?
Shelley. The Tower of Famine. It just leapt to mind. “Of all their beauty, and their hair and hue
The life of their sweet eyes with all its error,
Should be absorbed till they to marble grew.” Never met the man. Shelley. One day, perhaps I will.
It is not relevant. Continue!
FX: WHEEL TURNS AGAIN. RACK CREAKS
GASPS
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 77
SCENE 30: EXT. CASTLE COURTYARD
FX: CONTINUOUS FROM Sc. 28. YAVUZES STILL STRIDING FORWARD
(FX: NYSSA AND ROLAND RUSH UP AGAINST THE PORTCULLIS. THEY STOP)
(PANTING) The portcullis: a dead end. What do we do? My Lady???
(PANTING) The portcullis, of course! Here! Stand against the portcullis!
(FX: CLANG — ARMOUR AGAINST PORTCULLIS) And?
Let them attack us!
That is it???
At the last moment, when they raise their swords, step aside!
YAVUZ 3: (OFF) Strike! Strike!!!
FX: 4 x SCIMITARS RAISED — SHINK!
You are mad!!!
3: Trust me! NOW!!!
(FX: THEY DUCK OUT OF THE WAY AS THE SCIMITARS WHISTLE DOWN. 4 x SCIMITARS STRIKE PORTCULLIS — THEN — MASSIVE ELECTRICAL WHOMF ! )
CRY OUT) (FX: COLLAPSE TO FLOOR, SCIMITARS SCATTERED) (DIE
(BREATHLESS) They are — dead? Just by striking these bars?
Short-circuited!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 78
SCENE 31: INT. DUNGEON
FX: RACK TURNING
(PAIN) This is.. stretching a point too far.. don’t you think?
TOGETHER) (GASP SUDDENLY — THEIR POWER CUT OFF
Turn it, we said!
FX: BOTH YAVUZES COLLAPSE TO FLOOR. RACK WHEEL SPINS FREE
(EXHALES AS PRESSURE IS RELEASED SLIGHTLY) Your, uh, clones, appear to have — collapsed. Racked by remorse, perhaps. (BEAT) Drone leader?
(FX: FEEBLE CRACKLING) (WEAK) P-power circuit [is blown. ]
FX: CROSSFADE SHARPLY TO:
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 79
SCENE 32: EXT. CASTLE COURTYARD
YAVUZ 3/RUTAN 2:
(OFF, WEAK) [P-power circuit] is blown. (FX: RUTAN CRACKLING — HE’S CHANGING BACK) We cannot maintain this metamorphosis.
The last heathen! My Lady! He suffers — a transfiguration!
He’s changing, yes.
He is a demon!!!
He’s a jellyfish. A giant green jellyfish!
YAVUZ 3/RUTAN 2: (FX: BOBBING AWAY) We... withdraw...
Lycanthropy! (FX: DRAWING SWORD) I must slay him!
No! Let him go! He may still have some electrical charge left in him.
SCENE 33: INT. DUNGEON
(FX: WEAK CRACKLING) (GHOSTLY) Withdraw... withdraw...
FX: CRACKLING AWAY
(STILL IN RACK) Wait! Wait! You can’t just withdraw and leave me — (IT’S GONE; TO SELF) .. tied to this thing. (SIGHS)
Marvellous.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 80
SCENE 34: EXT. CASTLE COURTYARD
I said, let him go, Roland of Brittany!
It is my quest!
Your quest is for money, not death! Now — will you drop that sword?
(FX: CLATTER OF SWORD) (DEFENSIVE) I — I drop my weapon only so I might not succumb to more of this ‘eel-eck-tricks’!
Very wise. Might I suggest you remove your armour, too?
What, I must face this demon naked now?
No, just not wearing anything metal.
Then I will be safe?

Safer than the Knights who’ve faced this force before. Remember all those brave men in the courtyard — your own men, too — they were dressed head to foot in steel. The only one who’s faced these creatures and survived was a peasant in rags. Which reminds me: where is Osbert?
Fled, along with the noble Earl of Mummerset.

Let’s hope neither of them saw fit to use Hubert’s sword on the soldiers. Anyway, we’ll think about Osbert and Hubert later. Right now, our priority is you. So strip! (BEAT) Well? What’s stopping you?
(COY) My Lady.
(SIGHS) I’1l1 turn my back, shall I?
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 8]
SCENE 35: INT. DUNGEON
(OFF) Foolish peasant, are you [here-?] (WALKS INTO MAUD’S BODY IN PASSAGE) Aaaaaaggghhh!

Sir Doctor. The Yavuzes — they’ve vanished!

Like the twitchings of a decapitated limb?

Don’t tell me you want to get back in!

I’m afraid it’s too [early to say-]

Oh, you absolute [bounder! ]

ALOUD) I — I... (BEAT) I’m a-gettin’ out of here! (RUNS

Hubert, no! Don’t run!!!
Catch him! Hold him!!!
Yurr! Get him!
(FX: RUNNING, BUSTLING, STRUGGLING OFF AS THE VILLAGERS CATCH
(ASIDE, TO ROLAND) What exactly is it you’re playing at?

It’s quite simple, Sir Doctor. My noble quest is at an end. I have beaten the demons of Stockbridge Castle, to which there is no heir. In their gratitude, which of these peasants would deny me — the brave hero who so nobly vanquished their demons - the right to take these estates for my own?
The Rutan will be back, Roland. That I promise you!
. and you have shown me how to defeat it. In the morning, I shall destroy this waterwheel, then what can this ‘Rutan’ do?
You have no idea what it is you’re dealing with! None at all!
(OFF, BEING DRAGGED FORWARD) Smithy, please!
(TO ROLAND) Here he is, Sir Roland! Shall we brand him?
GROAN — TYPICAL OF SMITHY
No! No branding! There is only one way these demonic consorts may be freed of their sins!
(SIGHS) ‘Burn them’, I suppose?
Exactly! BURN THEM!!!
CHANTING) BURN THEM!!! (FX: REPEAT THROUGH CROSSFADE TO:

(OFF) Bring them devil-worshippers here! (BEAT) Anything more we can do for you, sire?
No, no... not for the moment.
Right you are, Sir Roland, sire.
(FX: IN CHAINS, BEING ESCORTED ACROSS) ‘Sir Roland’? The villagers have knighted you already?
A misapprehension I choose not to correct, Doctor. Now hurry along.
(FX: CHAINS, ESCORTED ACROSS) You try hurrying in chains!
Bind them to the stakes!
(BEING BOUND BY THE SMITHY) People of Stockbridge! Hear me! Roland of Brittany is not your saviour!
Durr, course he ain’t. We knows that.
What? Then why are you obeying his orders?
Cos — well, cos we’re serfs, aren’t we?
I’m sorry, I don’t follow.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 103
Can’t be serfs if we ain’t in service to someone. Men of Stockbridge has been serfs of them in the Castle long as there’s cocks been crowing! Growin’ crops! Tillin’ fields! Spreadin’ muck!
(WALKING UP) Dirty jobs, Doctor, but someone has to do them!
Please! It’s not too late to consider a collectivist alternative!
This is the country! We does things just as we always have!
A brave stab at being Wat Tyler, Hubert. But I fear it’s a bit late to hope for a peasants’ revolt.
We ain’t peasants! We’re serfs!
Yurrrrrrrrr!
Ain't that right, Osbert?

Oh, look who it is! Osbert the coward. Came crawling back, did you?

Enough! Light the torches! BURN THEM!!!
TAKE UP CHANT — “BURN THEM!!!” OVER THIS:

SOTTO) Must have jumped the moat, I suppose. Who cares? (BEAT
Doctor — you’re not really a wizard, are you?
(SOTTO) I’m afraid not.
(SOTTO) Thought I’d check. Oh well. Glad I came to Stockbridge, all the same.
(SOTTO) Really?
(SOTTO) Burning to death’s not as bad as life everafter in one of Saladin’s jails. The stench is indescribable.
(ALOUD, OFF) Repent your sins! Before it is too late!
(SOTTO) What d’you reckon, Doctor? Any crimes you want absolved?
(SOTTO) I’m just sorry I dragged Nyssa into this. I hope she’s not —
(SOTTO) Hey — are the hairs standing up? On back of your neck?
(SOTTO) They are, actually. (SOMETHING’S UP — BUT WHAT?) They are..! And that smell, like ozone?
(SOTTO; HOPEFULLY) Perhaps the kindling’s damp?
(SOTTO) Static. It’s static! The electrical field!
(SOTTO) You and your ‘eel-eck-tricks’.
(SOTTO) You don’t understand! The electrical field should have been shut off! Instead, it’s being extended!

(SOTTO) Which means?
FX: CROSS TO:

Silence! Silence! (FX: VILLAGERS QUIETEN) (FX: HOLDING BURNING TORCH, FLICKERING) With this purifying flame, I, Roland of Brittany, declare the village of Stockbridge finally purged of demonic infestation.

Drones — advance!

YAVUZ 4/5/6/7: Scatter the humans.

Follow the female, Doctor. We are approaching your TARDIS now.

Nyssa. I don’t know what sort of arrangement it is you’ve come to with this creature and his clones —

That is, I mean to say — you’re not Nyssa. Are you? You’re a Rutan, too.

Wait here. (FX: OPENS DOOR, ENTERS)

So I tell you this, Drone Leader: I will stop you. I will stop at nothing to see your species driven out of the entire Mutter’s Spiral — (DOUBLE TAKE) I’m sorry, did you say ‘superior officer’?
(FX: OPENING, EXITING TARDIS DOOR) Quite right. Underling. (FX: CLOSES DOOR BEHIND)
‘Underling’?
Is that the component?
Hang on! That’s my energy lattice!
(SHARPLY) My energy lattice, you mean. (PLACING IT ON THE GROUND) There. Take it off the ground, and our deal is concluded, Drone Leader.
RUTAN/OSBERT: (FX: CRACKLING, TRANSFORMING BACK) It is. Nyssa of Traken.
You will install it exactly as I instructed?
OSBERT/RUTAN: Yes. The Rutan Empire salutes you.
Likewise, Drone Leader.
OSBERT/RUTAN: (CONFIDENTIALLY) Even if your drone management skills leave much to be desired.
What?!?

. in the moat. (BEAT) Now — is there any other peasant who

FX: SHARP CRACKLE

Nyssa, what on Earth is going on?
Return to your ship, Drone Leader. You don’t have much time.
OSBERT/RUTAN: (FX: BOBBING AWAY) Yes, Nyssa of Traken. We shall. The Rutan Empire salutes you! (EXITS)
(BREATHING A SIGH OF RELIEF) It’s alright, he’s gone.
Nyssa. Please don’t tell me you just gave the Rutans a highly sophisticated kinetic conversion unit —
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 113
. in exchange for your safety, yes. Their own energy lattice was damaged, and it’d take too long to grow another vessel, so they'd been forced to improvise a hopelessly inadequate solution —
. if only to maintain the sham-eleonic properties of their Spacecraft, which is mapped over the precise external dimensions of —
. the High Keep. That’s why it’s the only part of the castle —
. not covered in moss. (INNOCENTLY) Carry on.
Well. I observed that if the Rutans simply altered the shape of their existing energy field, they’d be able to reach out far enough to save my ‘underling’ from Roland of Brittany.

OSBERT/RUTAN: Excellent!

But that means —

(OFF) Look! The castle!

Page 118

Do? Errr...
(STRIDING UP) Nothing! Do absolutely nothing.
N-nothing, Sir Doctor?
The demons are seeking to leave this planet. But their, uh, sky-boat is aflame.
‘Sky-boat’?
Nyssa, don’t patronise them. The aliens’ shameleonic vessel is essentially amorphous, but with its energy converters unconstrained, it’s expanding uncontrollably.
(SLOWLY) Then their — sky-boat — is... blowing... up?
FX: DISTANT FIREBALLS ERUPTING FROM SHIP
Like a balloon! (WARNING) Heads!
FX: FIREBALL WHIZZING THROUGH AIR
Fireballs!
Yes, perhaps everyone ought to take cover?
A dragon! Saints preserve us! It’s a dragon!
No, it’s a Rutan spacecraft.
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 120
(SOTTO) I think we should patronise them, Doctor. (ALOUD) What do you think it is, Smithy? A giant green beast is hurling fireballs at you from the castle’s highest point! Of course it’s a dragon!
Nyssa?!?
(SOTTO) Don’t you see, Doctor? It’s the dragon! Like in the play? This is where that tradition started!
Yes, but —
(RUNNING ABOUT, HYSTERICAL) A dragon! A dragon from Hell!
Somebody save us! (ETC)
Run! Run!!!
(ALOUD) Please, everyone, try not to panic!
(ALOUD) I’ve clipped his wings, he shall not fly!
Then cut him down, or else we die!!!

FROM PART ONE:
I’ll clip his wings, he shall not fly; I’1ll cut him down, or else I die!

SCENE 58: EXT. BY MOAT
(FX: SUDDEN REVERSE THRUM. INRUSHING SOUND AS THE SHIP IMPLODES, COLLAPSING IN ON ITSELF)
(OVER NOISE) Sir Doctor? What is happening?
The ship’s imploding! Collapsing in on itself!
FX: SUDDENLY, THE SOUND IS GONE
. and that’s that.
What, the demons are defeated?
Conclusively!
God in Heaven! (FAINTS)
(WARNING) Hubert!
(CATCHING HIM) It’s alright, I’ve got him.
(RUSHING UP) What’s wrong with the Earl?
Doctor?
(EXAMINING HUBERT) Nothing I can see. Exhaustion, I'd say. Delayed shock, that sort of thing.
3: What he needs is some sort of tonic.
Hardly.
But — I got tonic. (FX: FUMBLING) Here, in me flagon!
CASTLE OF FEAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 122
Funny, that. Doctor, I think you ought to administer the potion.
What?
(FX: PASSING FLAGON) Maud the Withered makes it out of herbs and berries... Put hairs on your chest, that will, my Lady!
(STIRS, GROGGY) Whuh?
Just as well it’s not for me. Doctor?
Oh, if I must. (FX: CORK OUT OF BOTTLE)
(WOOZY) Smells of elderberries...

(OFF) Here, look — it’s Osbert! Coming down from the castle!

GASPS
The time travellers! Take them!

FX: FOOTSTEPS
Phwoagh! It smells!

(FX: CIRCUITS GURGLING AND BELCHING. THE DOCTOR PUNCHING BUTTONS, KNOTTING CABLES, RIPPING OPEN SHELL LAYERS)

(BREATHLESS, WHILST ATTEMPTING TO FIX THINGS) Oh, no. Atrial dys-rhythmia! The ship’s engines are fibrillating!

Doctor...

(SQUEEZING INTO SMALL AREA) I’m trying, Nyssa. It’s complicated. There should be some sort of metabolic fail-safe, if only I can find — (PAIN) Ow!

That bit’s hot.

I recommend not starting any long sentences.

Ah. I was hoping you wouldn’t ask that. If I can just manage to — (FX: AN ALARM SOUNDS ANGRILY, A SERIES OF BEEPS ESCALATE IN
) It’s too late... warp core ignition. I’m so sorry, Nyssa. It’s about to — [explode]
(FX: THE DOCTOR’S WORDS ARE CUT OFF BY A DEVASTATING EXPLOSION.
WHICH TURNS INTO A WARPING, ECHOING, PHASING, AS THOUGH TIME
ITSELF IS BEING RIPPED APART... TAKING US INTO THE CLOSING THEME) THE END
